xldoc.author: rbj

section.title: Background
section.abstract: How I came to write this page.

subsec.p: I have never before written about art, not at least, concrete art rather than art in the abstract. Nor has it ever occurred to me that I might, that I have anything to say about the works of particular artists that might conceivably be of interest.

This with good cause, for I have never done art. Not at least, visual art, as opposed to works in the various other art forms such as music and literature. Nor have I studied it, though I have picked up some slight appreciation of some parts of its history.

That I embark on this improbable enterprise does not mark a change in any of these disqualications, or even despite it all, that I have something to say which lovers of art will find to be interesting (though I don't rule that out).
It is more from compulsion that conviction that I now embark on this modest piece of, what might be called, naîve art criticism.

I visited the artists "cottage studio" in the expectation of being at best pleasantly impressed (as is my usual fate on these occasions), and found myself thinking as if I were in the face of great art in my backyard. I don't imagine myself qualified to judge whether art is "great" or not (not that I am convinved anyone else is), so I am not here to tell you that Hainee-jo is a new Picasso.

Still, I am going to talk as if she were, for that is how I found myself thinking, and it is my purpose here not to tell you the truth about Hainee-Jo's art, but to tell you the truth about how and what it made me feel and think.

One weekend not so long ago in Lincolnshire, a number of local artists opened their studios as part of an enterprise entitled "Art on the Map". Having been out to support our grandson's football team, my wife and I took in a couple of studios on our way home.

The second was Hainee-Jo's in the small Lincolnshire village of Fulbeck. Toad Hall is a tiny cottage which makes the traditional "two-up two-down" terraced house seem palatial. It is one-and-half up and down, for there are just two rooms at about 9 feet square, (one up one down) and some more space which might be 9 by 6. The two larger rooms were galleries, the smaller space on the ground floor was both lobby and what passed for a kitchen. upstairs this must have been in two parts, for I recall at the front the room which was presented as a studio, at about 6 foot square, and I imagine the remaining space may have been a tiny bathroom.
